bodyXML:
Back to wait-and-see mode.

The Bank of Korea held its key interest rate steady, a month after cutting the rate to a record-low 1.75 per cent.

The case for loose monetary easing is clear: growth is slowing, Korean inflation is running at a 16-year low and unemployment is running at a 12-month high.

But with household debts on the rise, Governor Lee Ju-Yeol could be reluctant to cut rates even further.

The decision to keep policy steady syncs with decisions this week from Australia, Japan and India.

The BoK was largely expected to hold fire. Those expecting a cut this quarter include BNP Paribas, DBS, Deutsche Bank, and Societe Generale.
title: Bank of Korea keeps rates at 1.75%
